user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_fs_grow:
```c
int lfs_fs_grow(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_size_t block_count) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_fs_grow(%p, %"PRIu32")", (void*)lfs, block_count);

    err = lfs_fs_grow_(lfs, block_count);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_fs_grow -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_fs_grow:
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
static int lfs_fs_grow_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_size_t block_count) {
    int err;

    if (block_count == lfs->block_count) {
        return 0;
    }

    
#ifndef LFS_SHRINKNONRELOCATING
    // shrinking is not supported
    LFS_ASSERT(block_count >= lfs->block_count);
#endif
#ifdef LFS_SHRINKNONRELOCATING
    if (block_count < lfs->block_count) {
        err = lfs_fs_traverse_(lfs, lfs_shrink_checkblock, &block_count, true);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }
#endif

    lfs->block_count = block_count;

    // fetch the root
    lfs_mdir_t root;
    err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &root, lfs->root);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // update the superblock
    lfs_superblock_t superblock;
    lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_get(lfs, &root, LFS_MKTAG(0x7ff, 0x3ff, 0),
            LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_INLINESTRUCT, 0, sizeof(superblock)),
            &superblock);
    if (tag < 0) {
        return tag;
    }
    lfs_superblock_fromle32(&superblock);

    superblock.block_count = lfs->block_count;

    lfs_superblock_tole32(&superblock);
    err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &root, LFS_MKATTRS(
            {tag, &superblock}));
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    return 0;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other parts of the function and the additional code do not show statically unreachable code and therefore do not need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 in this snippet: - Calls and returns inside lfs_fs_grow_ (for example the early return when block_count == lfs->block_count, the multiple error checks and returns, and the final return) are conditional on runtime values and thus not provably unreachable from the source shown. - The conditional compilation blocks (#ifdef / #ifndef LFS_SHRINKNONRELOCATING) produce code that may or may not be present depending on build configuration; reachability of those blocks cannot be decided from the provided snapshot and so they should be evaluated in the build context rather than flagged here. - LFS_TRACE and LFS_UNLOCK macros (as shown) expand to no-ops and do not introduce unreachable branches in the surrounding code. Therefore they are not included as suspicious fragments to investigate further.
